msIdentifier.collection: Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, Main Collection

note.p: Adelbert Ames served as a governor and U.S. senator of Mississippi during the Reconstruction era. He was born in East Thomaston (modern-day Rockland), Maine, in 1835. As a boy, Ames spent time working on various merchant vessels, receiving training in seamanship. He entered the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1856, graduating in May 1861, at the start of the Civil War. Commissioned as a second lieutenant, the young Ames was promoted to first lieutenant barely over a week later and served with the 5th U.S. Artillery during the battle of First Bull Run at Manassas, Virginia, on July 21, 1861. Despite being wounded in the leg, Ames stayed by his cannons. His actions at Bull Run led him to receive the brevet (honorary) rank of major and, in 1893 (more than thirty years later), the Medal of Honor.

Ames recovered from his wound and returned to the front lines in 1862, serving with distinction as an artillery officer during the Peninsula Campaign near Richmond. Seeking better promotion potential, Ames sought an infantry command. Through those efforts, in August 1862, he received command of the 20th Maine Infantry Regiment, and led that unit in combat during the Battle of Fredericksburg in December 1862. In May 1863, he volunteered to serve as a staff officer for Major General George G. Meade, which helped him achieve the rank of brigadier general that month. With this promotion, Ames left the 20th Maine to his second-in-command, Lieutenant Colonel Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain, who gained great fame commanding the regiment at Little Round Top during the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863. Ames’ own performance at Gettysburg was highly praised, as his division successfully defended the Union position at Cemetery Hill.

After Gettysburg, Ames’ division was transferred to the Department of the South. Over the next two years, he commanded Union troops during campaigns in Florida, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. He received a brevet promotion to major general for his actions at Fort Fisher, North Carolina, in March 1865.

After the Civil War, Ames became involved in federal Reconstruction efforts. In 1868, he was appointed the provisional governor of Mississippi. Ames proved sympathetic to the plight of African Americans in the south. He sought to protect Black civil rights and appointed Mississippi’s first African American public officials. In 1870, after Mississippi was readmitted into the Union, Ames ran for U.S. senator for the state as a Republican and won. He served in that capacity from February 1870 to January 1874, achieving the reputation as a strong public speaker. While serving as a senator in Washington, D.C., Ames met and married Blanche Butler, daughter of Union general Benjamin F. Butler, under whom Ames had served during the war. Ames and his wife had six children over the course of their marriage.

In 1873, Ames ran for governor of Mississippi. His chief rival was James L. Alcorn, a former Confederate general who had been a Whig before the Civil War and joined the Republican Party afterwards. Ames won the election and worked diligently to improve Mississippi’s financial and social situation. In 1874, Democrats in Mississippi coordinated a campaign of violence against African Americans and white Republicans in the state, to secure political control in Mississippi. Unable to militarily suppress the white supremacist terror campaign, Ames signed a truce with Democratic leaders in Mississippi to reduce the violence and allow a peaceful election. Groups of white supremacists abandoned the truce and resumed their intimidation tactics against Republicans and Black Mississippians during the following elections, leading to a surge of Democratic politicians taking office.

In 1876, the conservative Democrat majority in the Mississippi legislature tried to impeach Ames and many other Republican officials with trumped up charges of corruption. Despite a strong political force against him, Ames’ critics were unable to provide any evidence of impropriety. Nevertheless, because impeachment was politically driven, Ames could see that his future as governor was over and any effort on his part to legally defend himself would be personally and financially taxing. He and his attorneys reached an agreement with Democratic leaders to resign his office in exchange for dropping the legal charges. On March 29, 1876, after Democrats cancelled their legal proceedings, Ames vacated his position.

Ames left Mississippi and went into business in Minnesota with his father and brother. A short time later, he relocated to New York City and then Massachusetts, overseeing mills and various business interests. When the Spanish-American War erupted in 1898, Ames volunteered for service and was appointed brigadier general of volunteers. Although over sixty years old, Ames joined the field campaign in Cuba and performed well.
Ames resumed his business ventures in the early twentieth century. He lived until 1933, dying at age 97. He is buried in Lowell, Massachusetts.
(Wikipedia)
Adelbert Ames belonged to the following social groups:

Dr. Fred Barrett was the private secretary of Mississippi governor Adelbert Ames during Reconstruction and a newspaper editor. Born on November 5, 1843, in Clearfield, Pennsylvania, Barrett graduated with a medical degree from Jefferson College in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in 1866, and practiced medicine in Pennsylvania for two years before moving to Mississippi during the Reconstruction era. He was an active member of the Republican Party and served in the Mississippi legislature for four years, before working as the private secretary of northern-born governor Adelbert Ames. Barrett also became involved in newspaper editing, managing the Southern Republican in the 1870s.

Barrett received a government job in Washington, D.C., after Reconstruction. He later moved to Wisconsin and then Minnesota, where he operated various newspapers. Barrett died in Tower, Minnesota, in 1895 at the age of 51 from Bright’s Disease. He was married to Caroline Redmond and had four children. He is buried in Lake View Cemetery in Tower, Minnesota.
(FindaGrave)
Fred Barrett belonged to the following social groups:
William McDavid Connor was a law enforcement officer in Mississippi during the late nineteenth century.

Born on December 30, 1822, in Hazel Green, Alabama, Connor moved to Mississippi and was elected sheriff of Noxubee County around the start of the Civil War. He served in that role through the war, keeping the peace and acting as tax collector in the county. Connor also served as sheriff in the 1870s. Connor died on May 7, 1901. He was married to a cousin, Sarah Jane Connor, and had at least nine children. He is buried in Connor Cemetery in Macon, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave; Macon Beacon, Macon, MS, March 30, 1864, and November 20, 1875)
William McDavid Connor belonged to the following social groups:
Ephraim Geoffrey Peyton, Jr. belonged to the following social groups:
Located in central Mississippi, Leake County was established on December 23, 1833 from Madison and Rankin counties. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Noxubee County, Macon was founded on August 10, 1835, and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia; Dunbar Rowland, Mississippi, Vol. 2, pg. 158)
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)

gloss.p: "A document consisting of news reports, articles, and photographs that is published every day or every week" (Cambridge Dictionary)

The first newspaper published in Mississippi was the Mississippi Gazette, which went into print around 1800 in Natchez, before Mississippi Territory was formally organized. Several more appeared during the next few years, and by the time Mississippi entered the Union in 1817 at least half a dozen different publications had emerged. Over the following years, newspaper companies opened as communities grew and the demand for information increased. Publishing resources (like paper and print presses) became more available aiding in the news media boom. By the mid-nineteenth century, most Mississippi towns or counties had a local newspaper, published daily or weekly. Major cities typically had more than one newspaper, often published by competing political parties. Most newspapers went out of business after only a few years; however, a few continued in print for decades, including The Columbus Democrat in Columbus (1836–1877), The Kosciusko Chronicle in Kosciusko (1846–1892), and the Grenada Sentinel of Grenada which started in 1868 and remained in publication until 1955. Overall, as many as two hundred different publishers started daily or weekly newspapers in Mississippi during the nineteenth century. (Tim Hughes, “The first newspapers in Mississippi…,” History’s Newsstand Blog; Library of Congress)

catDesc.term: Newspapers--Mississippi. Mississippi Daily and Weekly Pilot (Jackson, Miss.)

gloss.p: Located in Jackson, Mississippi, the Daily Mississippi Pilot was a semi-weekly newspaper company operating from 1868 until 1876. (Library of Congress)Located in Jackson, Mississippi, the Daily Mississippi Pilot was a semi-weekly newspaper company operating from 1868 until 1876. (Library of Congress)

When the 13th Amendment abolished slavery, it failed to abolish involuntary servitude. The amendment included a loophole banning involuntary servitude "except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted" (Library of Congress). White southerners in the post-emancipation South, concerned about both the availability of labor and the freedom of African Americans, manipulated this clause and turned to convict leasing to entrench long standing racial hierarchies.

Immediately after the war, many states passed "Black Codes" or laws severely limiting African Americans' rights. Under these codes and other similar laws passed in the decades following the Civil War, African Americans could be arrested for any number of petty crimes, including vagrancy (functionally construed to mean any act of social mobility not approved by a white person) or theft (in Mississippi a felony if exceeding $10 worth of goods). Widespread racism and stereotypes about Black criminality led to a dramatic expansion in the population of imprisoned individuals and an overwhelming number of African Americans within that population. Many states leased those convicted persons to private companies or individuals for their labor, and in certain cases lessees had been the pre-emancipation enslaver of the leased.

Laborers worked in a variety of settings including shipbuilding and timber cutting, yet the most prominent form in states like Mississippi remained large-scale agricultural work. The convict lease system was incredibly dangerous and difficult for those who lived through it, as leased persons faced unsafe working conditions, inadequate living conditions, abuse from lessees, and grueling work schedules. Given these circumstances, the ready availability of imprisoned laborers, and the callousness of lessees and state officials, the mortality rate among convict laborers was incredibly high.

Certain states ceased leasing imprisoned persons to individuals or private companies in the late nineteenth century, only to continue using that labor on state-funded infrastructure projects like road or highway construction until, in some cases, World War II. Southern individuals and states thereby continued to increase their wealth through the coerced labor of African Americans while perpetuating anti-Black racism and laying the foundations of the modern prison-industrial complex (Library of Congress; Mississippi Encyclopedia).

In the wake of the Civil War, many states turned to convict leasing to bolster infrastructural repair and to maintain long standing racial hierarchies. Like many other southern states, Mississippi instituted a convict leasing program, and in 1876 the state passed the Leasing Act (commonly known as the “Pig Law”), which sentenced anyone who stole property valued at $10 or greater up to five years in prison and quadrupled the prison population, with Black prisoners comprising approximately 85% of inmates. The state most frequently leased convicted persons to individuals, primarily to perform agricultural work on cotton farms.

However, the state also leased incarcerated persons to private companies, such as the Gulf & Ship Island Railroad Company, and companies subjected convict-laborers to excruciating working conditions with little shelter, sustenance, or medical care. While companies and private individuals leased enslaved workers during the antebellum era, enslavers expected “their human chattel to be returned alive and in good working condition” (Sturkey, Hattiesburg). However, this expectation was virtually nonexistent in postwar convict leasing programs. The death toll therefore grew to staggering heights. In response, Mississippi cancelled Gulf & Ship Island’s contract in December 1888 and ceased leasing convicts to private companies in 1890. However, the state and individual counties and towns continued to use convict labor for public works projects and at the state’s penitentiary at Parchman plantation well into the twentieth century (Mississippi Encyclopedia).
"Finance is the study and discipline of money, currency and capital assets." (Wikipedia)
"Debt is an obligation that requires one party, the debtor, to pay money borrowed or otherwise withheld from another party, the creditor." (Wikipedia)
Engaging in "illegal activities." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of killing a person when the killer did not intend to do it or cannot be responsible for his or her actions." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
"An amount of money set for a person accused of a crime to be released from a law enforcement facility until trial." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of putting someone in prison or the condition of being kept in prison." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"In law, a sentence is the punishment for a crime ordered by a trial court after conviction in a criminal procedure, normally at the conclusion of a trial. A sentence may consist of imprisonment, a fine, or other sanctions." (Wikipedia)

"A writ issued by an appellate court to the court of record where a case was tried, requiring that the record of the trial be sent to the appellate court for examination of alleged errors." (Dictionary.com)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A lawyer who acts for the government against someone accused of a crime in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)

“Someone who works in an office, writing letters, making phone calls, and arranging meetings for a person or for an organization.” (Cambridge Dictionary) CWRGM includes people who perform administrative assistance under this tag, but we do not include government positions that incorporate the word secretary, such as Secretary of State, under this subject tag.
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., a group of people who decide if a person who has been charged with a crime should be given a trial in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where criminals are kept as a punishment for their crimes or while waiting for trials." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Organizations -- U.S. State Governments
Organizations -- Legal Organizations

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Mississippi judiciary was established by Article 6 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890. It is one of three branches of the Mississippi state government, along with the executive branch and the legislative branch. The judiciary branch is composed of four tiers of court: limited jurisdiction, general jurisdiction, intermediate appellate, and last resort. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)

catDesc.term: Mississippi--Judiciary. High Court of Errors and Appeals
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Organizations -- U.S. State Governments
Organizations -- Legal Organizations

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Mississippi High Court of Errors and Appeals was created by the 1832 state constitution and was comprised of three popularly-elected justices. It remained the highest appellate court in the state until 1869, when it was replaced by the state Supreme Court. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

term.rs: Mississippi--Judiciary. High Court of Errors and Appeals

gloss.p: "Mississippi State Penitentiary, also known as Parchman Farm, is a maximum-security prison farm located in unincorporated Sunflower County, Mississippi, in the Mississippi Delta region. Occupying about 28 square miles (73 km2) of land, Parchman is the only maximum security prison for men in the state of Mississippi, and is the state's oldest prison." (Wikipedia)

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

div.p: [note]6/11/74[/note]

The State of Mississippi
Noxubee County.

Circuit Court
Saturday the 6"day 2nd week. 19" October 1867.
Court met persuant to ajournment at 8. O Clock A. M. Prt His Honor. H. W. Forte presiding. Judg of sixth Judicial District of the State of Mississippi:
Be it remembered that on said day. Among- other things the following order was Entered on the minutes of said Court To Wit:

The State
1401.vs. John. S. Edwards

On this day by order of the Court the pris-oner John S. Edwards—is brought into open court by the Sheriff from the Jail to receive his sentence upon the conviction by the Jury rendered at a former day of the term of the Court: And it is considered by the Court that the said John S. Edwards for such his offense be—forthwith taken hence by the Sheriff of this County and remanded to Jail and from thence to the peniteniary of the State and be there confined and Kept at hard labor according to the statute governing the same for the

[fuel?] period of Four. years. from and after this day and thereupon the defendant prayd a writ of Error in this Cause which is granted by the Court. and thereupon the said defendant John. S. Edwards and his surities Alfred Moore A. Gillis. Gosper Kinard. J S. White and Jacob. Kinard acknowledged themselves to owe and be indebted to owe and be indebted to the State of Mississippi the sum of seven Hundred Dollars, that is to Say the Said defendent in the sum of Seven Hundred Dollars and his said surities in the like sum of Seven hundred Dollars to be hired of their goods and chaltlet lands and tenements. but to be void upon the condition that the Defen-dant shall well and truly pay the Cash of this prosecution both in this Court and in the High Court of Errors. and appeals in cse the Judgment of this Court shall be affirmed and the Said defendant John. S. Edwars. being admitted to bail in the sum of Two Thousand—Dollars. He and his Said Surities. Alfred Moore A. Gillis Gosper Kinard. J. S. White

and Jacob Kinard farther acknowledged themselves to owe and be indebted to the State of Mississippi in the sum of Two Thousand Dollars; that is to say the said defendant in the sum of two thousand—Dollars. and his said surities in the like sum of Two Thousand Dollars to be [levied?] of their goods and chattles lands and tenements to but to be void upon the condition that the said defendant, John S- Edwards shall make his personal appearance before the High Court of Errors and appeals to be holden at the City of Jackson on the 1st Monday of December A D 1867—and shall attend from day to day and from term to term until discharged by due course of law and shall do and per-form all the orders and abide the sentences and decrees both of this court and of the High Court of Errors and appeals aforesaith
[seal]

The State of Mississippi
Noxubee County
I. T. J. White Clerk of the Circuit Court in and for said county & state do hereby certify that the

withinand foregoing is a true and complete copy of the sentence—and order of the Court rendered in said County on the 19" day of October 1874 as truly and completely as the same appears of record in my office on Minute Book "H" Pages. 286 & 287.
Given under my hand and seal of office.at Macon on this the 11" day of June A D 1874.

T. J. White Clerk
By W H Kinnon D. C.
[seal]

1401
The State copy of order & sentence
John S. Edwards

The State of Mississippi
Hinds County.

[H?] To the Sheriff of Noxubee County. Greeting: Whereas by the judgment of our Supreme Court rendered in the cause of John S. Edwards vs. The State of Mississippi on writ of error from the Circuit Court of Noxubee County, the said John S. Edwards for the crime of man=slaughter whereof he was convicted, was sentenced to four years imprisonment in the Penitentiary said term to begin with his reception at said Penitentiary, You are therefore hereby commanded to take the body of the said Jno S. Edwards, and him safely keep, to await the order of the Keeper of the Penitentiary in this behalf. Herein fail not:
Witness the Hon E. G. Peyton Chief Justice on the third Monday of April 1872. Witness also the signature of the Clerk of and seal of said Supreme Court this 28th day of June A. D. 1872

J. M. McKee Clerk
By McWillick D. C
[seal]
[seal]

State
vs
Order for arrest

John S Edwards
Recd July 8/72
W M Conner [?]
CAPIAS.—Printed and for sale at the Pilot Book and Job Office, Jackson, Miss.

The State of Mississippi,
Noxubee COUNTY.
TO THE SHERIFF OF SAID ^Leake^ COUNTY --Greeting.

WE COMMAND YOU to take the body of John S. Edwards, if to be found in your County, and him safely keep, so that you have his body before the Honorable, the Circuit Court of Noxubee County, in said State, to holden at the Court House thereof, in the town of Macon, on the First Mondy in June A. D. 1874, then and there to answer unto the State of Misissippi of a charge of Manslaughter of which Crime the said Deft was convicted and the Judgement of this court affirmed by the Supreme Court by information filed in said Court, at the Term, A. D. 187, thereof.
Herein fail not, and have then there this writ, with the manner you have executed the same.
GIVEN UNDER MY HAND AND SEAL, and issued the 11" day of June A. D. 1874

T. J. White
Clerk.
[seal]
Leake Co.

The State
VS. } CAPIAS.
John S. Edward

EXECUTIVE OFFICE,
STATE OF MISSISSIPPI.
Leake County.
Copy of Order & Sentence, Order for arrest, And Capias, in the Case of the State Vs John S Edwards for Manslaughter

FRED. BARRETT,
Private Secretary.
